overview_of_class: This course will focus on the question of what constitutes a just political society. Students will be introduced to some of the central theories of justice in the Western philosophical tradition, including liberalism, utilitarianism, Marxism, and libertarianism. More specifically, we will be addressing questions like: How much inequality should be allowed in a just society? To what extent does the redistribution of wealth infringe on individual liberty? What rights do individuals have against the state? What kinds of responsibilities come with citizenship?
name: Introduction to Political Philosophy
title: WCAS PHIL 261-0-20 Introduction to Political Philosophy

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will:
1.Gain an understanding of the different principles and ideals of political morality that motivate a diverse range of political views.
2.Develop the ability to articulate what is at issue in debates about the relation between public and private responsibility for various aspects of citizens' lives.
3.Learn to identify and reconstruct the main arguments and assumptions found in philosophical texts.
4.Work on writing a clear thesis and present a thoughtful argument in support of that thesis.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Short writing assignments, midterm exam, final essay
